newsitem.title: USA: US House ag chair plans market-opening trips.
newsitem.headline: US House ag chair plans market-opening trips.

text.p: The chairman of the U.S. House Agriculture Committee said Tuesday that he would work commodity by commodity and country by country to increase U.S. farm exports.

During a speech to the Commodity Club of Washington, chairman Bob Smith, an Oregon Republican, said he planned trips to Mexico, Canada and Europe in coming months to work on farm trade issues. Smith visited Chile and Argentina earlier this year.
Trade negotiators often talk in generalities, Smith said, but "I'm going to speak in specifics." The approach, he said, worked before, such as opening Japan to beef imports.
He invited the group, whose members include lobbyists, agribusiness executives and representatives of farm groups, to suggest commodities and nations that deserve attention.
"We do plan to go to the European Union and discuss our issues with them," Smith said. "We do plan before the year is over to go to the European Union."
Smith said he also wanted to discuss the performance of the North American Free Trade Agreement with officials in Mexico and Canada, "not to eliminate NAFTA but to prove what is happening with us."
The United States has a bundle of farm trade disagreements with each of the three trading partners.

Chile and Argentina ship far more agricultural products to the U.S. market than the United States ships to them. He said Chile and Argentina employed unfair grading and sanitary standards that blocked U.S. livestock and grain sales.
"There's a possibility we can open up the wheat market in Chile," he said.
